p: In the present study, the larvicidal activity of Plumbago auriculata Lam. was explored by the use of AgNPs. As seen from previous reports [ 29, 30], the naphthoquinone compound plumbagin is found to be predominantly present in the Plumbaginaceae plant family. In particular, Maniafu et al. [ 29] reported the presence of two compounds, viz. 5-hydroxy-2-methyl-1,4-naphthoquinone (plumbagin)’ and β-sitosterol, in the crude extracts from three Plumbago spp. Plumbago zeylanica ( P. zeylanica) Linn, Plumbago dawei ( P. dawei) Rolfe, and Plumbago stenophylla Bull. They attributed plumbagin to be primarily responsible for the larvicidal activity against Anopheles gambiae. In a similar work, the root compound of plumbagin from Plumbago zeylanica was evaluated for antimalarial activity against the fourth instar larvae of Anopheles stephensi [ 30]. In 2014, Deshpande et al. [ 41] reported the presence of plumbagin in the leaves of Plumbago auriculata Lam. Hence, based on these observations, the present study focused on performing molecular docking of plumbagin with the mosquito salivary proteins.
